 In colonial times there were no police as we know them today. Oh, some of the larger townships may have a marshall, but it fell within the particular area in which one lived, to furnish the 'policing' of their location. Each location, area, or subarea, had its own militia. It was incumbent upon all men attaining age 16, ( heavens, that will blow the antigunners minds ) or just moving into the district to present himself for militia duty. He was required to furnish, at his own expense, a rifle or musket of the type being used by regular troops, so much shot and powder, a certain amount of provisions, and a blanket. Upon being enrolled in the militia, he was to present himself, along with the other militiamen of that district, upon the 'green' for drill and marksmanship training. Hence the term, well regulated. If the young man or the new man in town did not attain unto himself the necessary accoutements, even if he had to borrow the money, he could be put into servitude until the debt was paid. (Very early conscription, BTW ) It was his responsibility to be well armed at his own expense. In earlier times, that requirement lasted until age 60, but under the Militia Act of 1792, I believe, it was dropped to age 45.
